239 of Zoar must be there also .Ibn id War di says : * * * and from Jaffa to Zoar ( in width or longitude ) , which is the city of the people of Lot , and the sea by it is caUed the stinking sea , and from it to Beisan and Tiberias is caUed the Ghor , for it is a plain between two mountains ( p .178 ) .

As the term Arabia was sometimes apphed to the whole country east of the Jordan , and sometimes ( in Josephus ) to the country bordering upon the Dead Sea on the east , it does not necessarily follow that by of he meant some place south of the Dead Sea , although this is probable .We present here a few quotations from Arab writers , which bear upon this question : Abulfeda quotes from Ibn Hakel , and apparently adopts as his own , the foUowing statement : And from the stinking stinking [ Dead ] Sea and Zoar to Beisan and Tiberias , it is caUed the Ghor , for it is between two mountains .AU the land of Syria is elevated above it , and some of it belongs to the Jordan and some to He adds further : Ibn Hakel says : ' The Ghor has its beginning at the Sea of Tiberias , and then extends by Beisan untd it ends at Zoar and Jericho at the Dead Sea .

We now found ourselves hi a broad street which had dweUings on both sides of it , whose height and width left nothing to be desired .The temperature temperature was mdd , the air free from unpleasant odors , and I felt not the shghtest difficulty in breathing .Farther along there were several cross - streets , and my guide caUed my attention to a rosen ( a window or hole in the ceiling for air ) , which , like three others that I saw afterwards , was closed up from above .

They are aU sidphur springs .The whole region is filled with the odor .The first night we spent here , I awoke , and , not remembering for an instant exactly where I was , but perceiving perceiving the strong odor which fided the vaUey , I exclaimed : What is it But a few days ' experience accustomed me to the smeU , and I either hke it , or else have persuaded my7 - self my7 - self that I do , for I reaUy enjoy being here .

This is the retem bush , which grows so abundantly7 along the Zerka , and farther south , in the region east of the Dead Sea .The flower is small , but very fragrant .The blossoms are profuse , profuse , and resemble the arbutus in color and smell .

They had been gone some weeks , having migrated to other sections .StiU , without the debris of various kinds , the usual odor was sufficient evidence that they had been there .220 EAST OF THE JORDAN .

The wind blew and the rain beat so that I could not have much hght in my tent , and the next day was endured , rather than enjoyed or improved .Besides , our tent was made unusuaUy disagreeable by a bad smell .Van Dyck was fortunate enough to shoot a pair ( male and female ) of griffon vultures .
